intro: Passerina inconspicua, commonly known as the inconspicuous pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, usually yellow or white flowers. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine habitats, thriving in well-drained, rocky soils. Its leaves are palmately compound, with finely divided leaflets, and it blooms in late spring to early summer. Passerina inconspicua is known for its delicate appearance and is often found in meadows and open slopes at high elevations.
